page.title: 05THE GREAT LAKE AT BEDGEBURY
page.content: This is an artificial lake, with a dam at its north end, on a tributary of the River Teise. It has an area of about 7 hectares and is about 3 metres deep over much of this. Besides amenity and recreation, the impounded water was used from 1855 till recently to drive a hydraulic ram to pump water to a nearby reservoir for supply to local farms and dwellings. The lake is used by the Cranbrook and District Angling Club and by the Bedgebury Park Sailing Club which has a fleet of six Torch sailing dinghies and a motor boat. Wildlife at present includes a pair of mute swans, mallard ducks, freshwater mussels and several species of fish. In 1984 there was also a pair of herons. There are some areas of water lilies and there is woodland along three-quarters of its perimeter.
